shortname: Consumption of fixed capital of corporations
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2013–2016: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1951–2012: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2017–2019: imputed value; 2014–2016: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1951–2013: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL]1950: imputed value. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2016: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/chancelpiketty2017widworld/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas (2017).Indian Income inequality, 1922-2015: From British Raj to Billionaire Raj?[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: Tax units are individuals (40% of total population). Excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2013 from: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 1950–2019: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].

We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2016: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/n-k-bharti-wealth-inequality-class-and-caste-in-india-1961-2012/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Nitin Kumar Bharti (2018), Wealth Inequality, Class and Caste in India[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: In 1961 and 1971 data covers rural areas only. Net wealth is reported since 1981. In 1971, net wealth is estimated using the liabilies at the bracket level (assuming individuals remain in the same bracket). In 1961, liabilities are estimated assuming the liability/gross wealth ratios at the bracket level from 1971, and using the 1971 proportions of individuals having any kind of liability. In 2002 and 2012 series are corrected using Forbes lists, and the top of the survey distribution is replaced by a Pareto distribution.

simpledes: Net domestic product is the total value of the goods and services produced in a country, minus the value of the fixed capital used up in production (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads).The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net domestic product]=[Gross domestic product]-[Consumption of fixed capital of national economy]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from abroad]-[Property income paid abroad]+[Compensation of employees received from abroad]-[Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world]

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1950–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.

We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Book-value national wealth is the sum of value of assets according to the books (balance sheets) on which they are carried. It is the difference between net national wealth and national net corporate wealth. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Book-value national wealth]=[National non-financial assets (book value value)]+[Net foreign assets]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Book-value wealth equals aggregate measure for domestic produced assets + land of housing, corporations and government + net foreign assets.

simpledes: Net foreign assets are the total value of the assets that a country owns abroad, minus the total value of the domestic assets owned by foreigners. technicaldes: [Net foreign assets]=[Gross foreign assets]-[Gross foreign liabilities]

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

technicaldes: [Net portfolio income]=[Net portfolio income, officially recorded]+[Net reinvested earnings on foreign portfolio investment]+[Received from tax havens]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Average income or wealth between two percentiles. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', intermediary average returns the average between percentile pX and the next consecutive percentile. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/chancelpiketty2017widworld/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas (2017).Indian Income inequality, 1922-2015: From British Raj to Billionaire Raj?[/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/indian-inequality-updates-2015-2019-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-09/[/URL_LINK][/URL_TEXT] Updated by Chancel, “Regional DINA update for India” (2020)[/URL][URL_TEXT]
method: 1922-1950: tax data from Indian Tax Department; 1950-2014: Tax data from Indian Tax Department and Survey data from NSS0, using IHDS to convert survey consumption into survey income (see Chancel Piketty 2019 for details). After 2014, values are extrapolated assuming inequality neutral growth rates. The World Inequality Lab is currently updating 2015-2019 estimates using newly released tax data. This information will be uploaded online shortly.

Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the variable returns the average between percentiles pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2016: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1975–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1970–1974: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/chancelpiketty2017widworld/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas (2017).Indian Income inequality, 1922-2015: From British Raj to Billionaire Raj?[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: Tax units are individuals (40% of total population). Excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/n-k-bharti-wealth-inequality-class-and-caste-in-india-1961-2012/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Nitin Kumar Bharti (2018), Wealth Inequality, Class and Caste in India[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: In 1961 and 1971 data covers rural areas only. Net wealth is reported since 1981. In 1971, net wealth is estimated using the liabilies at the bracket level (assuming individuals remain in the same bracket). In 1961, liabilities are estimated assuming the liability/gross wealth ratios at the bracket level from 1971, and using the 1971 proportions of individuals having any kind of liability. In 2002 and 2012 series are corrected using Forbes lists, and the top of the survey distribution is replaced by a Pareto distribution.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: The beta coefficient corresponds to the inverted Pareto-Lorenz coefficient. It is equal to mean income over a certain income level divided by this level. A coefficient b=2=200% for an income level 100 000 EUR means that the average income above 100 000 EUR is 200 000 EUR, a coefficient of 3 or 300% at income level 1 000 000 EUR means that the average income level above 1 000 000 EUR in a given population is 3 000 000 EUR.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/chancelpiketty2017widworld/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas (2017).Indian Income inequality, 1922-2015: From British Raj to Billionaire Raj?[/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/indian-inequality-updates-2015-2019-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-09/[/URL_LINK][/URL_TEXT] Updated by Chancel, “Regional DINA update for India” (2020)[/URL][URL_TEXT]
method: 1922-1950: tax data from Indian Tax Department; 1950-2014: Tax data from Indian Tax Department and Survey data from NSS0, using IHDS to convert survey consumption into survey income (see Chancel Piketty 2019 for details). After 2014, values are extrapolated assuming inequality neutral growth rates. The World Inequality Lab is currently updating 2015-2019 estimates using newly released tax data. This information will be uploaded online shortly.

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: The Gini coefficient is a measure of statistical dispersion. A coefficient of zero expresses perfect equality between individuals. A coefficient of one expresses maximal inequality, where only one person owns all the income or wealth of the economy.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/chancelpiketty2017widworld/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas (2017).Indian Income inequality, 1922-2015: From British Raj to Billionaire Raj?[/URL_TEXT][/URL];

simpledes: Current national income adjusted by CPI, divided by national income of the base year adjusted by CPI. It measures the changes in the purchasing power of national income.
longtype: Indices
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.worldbank.org/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]World Bank[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL
method: We cumulate inflation rates from the following sources; 1901-2012: price index provided by the researchers (see source); 2013-2018: GDP deflator from the World Bank; 2019: CPI from the World Bank.

simpledes: Index that reflects the availability of surveys and tax data enabling the measurement of income and wealth inequality.
longtype: Indices
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/transparency/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Inequality Transparency Index Methodology[/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/inequality-transparency-index-update-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-12/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]; Burq, François and Chancel, Lucas. Inequality transaprency index update (2020)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: The inequality transparency index is estimated by the World Inequality Lab based on the availability of income and wealth surveys and tax data in the country considered. See http://wid.world/transparency/ for more information .

shortname: Consumption of fixed capital of corporations
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL][URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2013–2016: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1951–2012: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

shortname: Compensation of employees paid from the rest of the world
simpledes: Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world is the total value of income accruing to employees as remuneration for their work.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

simpledes: Consumption of fixed capital of national economy is the decline in total value of fixed assets (e.g. roads, machines) which are owned and used by a producer. In other words, the amounts required to maintain the quality of fixed assets from a year to another. The decline in  value is a result of physical deterioration, normal obsolescence or normal accidental damage.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2011–2016: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (2008)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1999–2010: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1993)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1980–1998: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.un.org/Explorer.aspx[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]UN SNA (1968)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Gross domestic product is the total value of goods and services produced by the national economy.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See DINA guidelines for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL].
method: We use the GDP level in 2013 from: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. (2014), Capital is Back: Wealth-Income Ratios in Rich Countries 1700-2010, Quarterly Journal of Economics, 129(3): 1255-1310 (series updated by the same authors)[/URL_TEXT][/URL]. Then we cumulate growth rates from the following sources; 1950–2019: [URL][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/piketty-t-and-zucman-g-2014-capital-is-back-wealth-income-ratios-in-rich-countries-1700-2010quarterly-journal-of-economics-1293-1255-1310/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Piketty T. and Zucman G. longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1950–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Net domestic product is the total value of the goods and services produced in a country, minus the value of the fixed capital used up in production (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads).The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net domestic product]=[Gross domestic product]-[Consumption of fixed capital of national economy]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

simpledes: Net foreign income is the difference between the total value of a country's citizens and companies earned abroad, and the total value of foreign citizens and overseas companies earned in that country.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Net foreign income]=[Property income received from abroad]-[Property income paid abroad]+[Compensation of employees received from abroad]-[Compensation of employees paid to rest of the world]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: See [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL] for methodological explanations. The sources used are: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL.
method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 2019: extrapolated from last available year; 2014–2018: [URL][URL_LINK]http://data.imf.org/BOP[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]IMF Balance of Payments Statistics[/URL_TEXT][/URL]; 1951–2013: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: National income aims to measure the total income available to the residents of a given country. It is equal to the gross domestic product (the total value of goods and services produced on the territory of a given country during a given year), minus fixed capital used in production processes (e.g. replacement of obsolete machines or maintenance of roads) plus the net foreign income earned by residents in the rest of the world.// National income has many limitations, however it is the only income concept that has an internationally agreed definition (established by the United Nations System of National Accounts, see SNA 2008). We thus use it as our reference concept (after corrections to include income hidden in tax havens). // The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [National income]=[Net domestic product]+[Net foreign income]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.

method: WID.world estimations as a proportion of GDP based on the following; 1950–2019: estimated from other components. These estimates are then anchored to GDP (see GDP variable for details). simpledes: Book-value national wealth is the sum of value of assets according to the books (balance sheets) on which they are carried. It is the difference between net national wealth and national net corporate wealth. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.
technicaldes: [Book-value national wealth]=[National non-financial assets (book value value)]+[Net foreign assets]
longtype: Macroeconomic variable (i.e. corresponding to national economy rather than to a given group of individuals). The associated percentile is of the form 'pall'.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Book-value wealth equals aggregate measure for domestic produced assets + land of housing, corporations and government + net foreign assets.

simpledes: Gross foreign assets are the total value of the assets that country owns abroad. The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

shortname: Property income paid from the rest of the world
simpledes: Property income paid abroad is the total value of payments made by the national economy accruing to property owners as remuneration for using their property.The national economy - in the national accounts sense - includes all domestic sectors, i.e. all entities that are resident of a given country (in the sense of their economic activity), whether they belong to the private sector, the corporate sector, the governement sector.

The estimates of national accounts subcomponents in the WID are based on official country data and use the methodology presented in the [URL][URL_TEXT]DINA guidelines[\URL_TEXT][URL_LINK]https://wid.world/document/distributional-national-accounts-guidelines-2020-concepts-and-methods-used-in-the-world-inequality-database/[\URL_LINK][\URL]. We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

We stress that these subcomponents estimates are more fragile than those of main aggregates such as national income. Countries may use classifications used are not always fully consistent with other countries or over time. Series breaks with no real economic significance can appear as a result. The WID include these estimates to provide a centralized source for this official data, so that it can be exploited more directly. We encourage users of this data to be careful and to pay attention to the source of the data, which we systematically indicate.

simpledes: Number of adults as tax units.
longtype: Number of units in a given group
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: Banerjee, Abhijit and Piketty, Thomas (2005). Top Indian Incomes 1922-2000; in Atkinson, A. B. and Piketty, T. (editors) Top Incomes: A Global Perspective, Oxford University Press, chapter 1.;
method: Individuals (40% of total population).

simpledes: Number of reports filed containing information used to calculate taxes.
longtype: Number of units in a given group
longpop: The base unit is the tax unit defined by national fiscal administrations to measure personal income taxes.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: Banerjee, Abhijit and Piketty, Thomas (2005). Top Indian Incomes 1922-2000; in Atkinson, A. B. and Piketty, T. (editors) Top Incomes: A Global Perspective, Oxford University Press, chapter 1.;

simpledes: Fiscal income is defined as the sum of all income items reported on income tax returns, before any deduction. It includes labour income, capital income and mixed income. The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.
technicaldes: [Fiscal income ]=[Fiscal labour income ]+[Fiscal capital income ]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/chancelpiketty2017widworld/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas (2017).Indian Income inequality, 1922-2015: From British Raj to Billionaire Raj?[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: Tax units are individuals (40% of total population). Excludes capital gains.

simpledes: Net personal wealth is  the total value of non-financial and financial assets (housing, land, deposits, bonds, equities, etc.) held by households, minus their debts. . The personal or household sector - in the national accounts sense - includes all households and private individuals (including those living in institutions), as well as unincorporated enterprises whose accounts are not separated from those of the households who own them.
technicaldes: [Net personal wealth]=[Personal non-financial assets]+[Personal financial assets]-[Personal debt]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/n-k-bharti-wealth-inequality-class-and-caste-in-india-1961-2012/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Nitin Kumar Bharti (2018), Wealth Inequality, Class and Caste in India[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: In 1961 and 1971 data covers rural areas only. Net wealth is reported since 1981. In 1971, net wealth is estimated using the liabilies at the bracket level (assuming individuals remain in the same bracket). In 1961, liabilities are estimated assuming the liability/gross wealth ratios at the bracket level from 1971, and using the 1971 proportions of individuals having any kind of liability. In 2002 and 2012 series are corrected using Forbes lists, and the top of the survey distribution is replaced by a Pareto distribution.

simpledes: Pre-tax national income  is the sum of all pre-tax personal income flows accruing to the owners of the production factors, labor and capital, before taking into account the operation of the tax/transfer system, but after taking into account the operation of pension system. The central difference between personal factor income and pre-tax income is the treatment of pensions, which are counted on a contribution basis by factor income and on a distribution basis by pre-tax income.
technicaldes: Pre-tax national income =Pre-tax labor income [total pre-tax income ranking]+Pre-tax capital income [total pre-tax income ranking]
longtype: Income or wealth shares. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pX', the raw data stores the share of total income or wealth detained by all the population between threshold pX and the top of the distribution. When the associated percentile is of the form 'pXpY', the raw data stores the share of the population between thresholds pX and pY.
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household) but resources are split equally within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals over age 20.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/chancelpiketty2017widworld/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Chancel, Lucas; Piketty, Thomas (2017).Indian Income inequality, 1922-2015: From British Raj to Billionaire Raj?[/URL_TEXT][/URL];[URL][URL_LINK]http://wordpress.wid.world/document/indian-inequality-updates-2015-2019-world-inequality-lab-technical-note-2020-09/[/URL_LINK][/URL_TEXT] Updated by Chancel, “Regional DINA update for India” (2020)[/URL][URL_TEXT]
method: 1922-1950: tax data from Indian Tax Department; 1950-2014: Tax data from Indian Tax Department and Survey data from NSS0, using IHDS to convert survey consumption into survey income (see Chancel Piketty 2019 for details). After 2014, values are extrapolated assuming inequality neutral growth rates. The World Inequality Lab is currently updating 2015-2019 estimates using newly released tax data. This information will be uploaded online shortly.

The concept of fiscal income varies with national tax legislations, so in order to make international comparisons it is preferable to use the concept of national income.

method: 1922-1950: tax data from Indian Tax Department; 1950-2014: Tax data from Indian Tax Department and Survey data from NSS0, using IHDS to convert survey consumption into survey income (see Chancel Piketty 2019 for details). After 2014, values are extrapolated assuming inequality neutral growth rates. The World Inequality Lab is currently updating 2015-2019 estimates using newly released tax data. This information will be uploaded online shortly.

shortname: Net national wealth to Net National Income Ratio
simpledes: Wealth-Income Ratio is the division of national wealth by national income.
longtype: Ratio of net wealth (of a given sector) to net national income
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://wid.world/document/the-evolution-of-wealth-income-ratios-in-india-1860-2012-wid-world-working-paper-2019-07/[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]Kumar, Rishabh (2019), The evolution of wealth-income ratios in India, 1860-2012[/URL_TEXT][/URL]
method: Wealth-income ratios for year t are computed as ratios of wealth_t and mean national income_t for (t-1, t, t+1) except for point estimates until 1901. Interpolations for book-value national wealth are based on multiplicative wealth equations.

shortname: PPP conversion factor, LCU per EUR
simpledes: PPP conversion factor of curent local currency to current PPP EUR.
longtype: Exchange rate series
longpop: The base unit is the individual (rather than the household). This is equivalent to assuming no sharing of resources within couples.
longage: The population is comprised of individuals of all ages.
source: [URL][URL_LINK]http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DataSetCode=PPP2011[/URL_LINK][URL_TEXT]OECD[/URL_TEXT][/URL];
method: We extrapolate the PPP from the latest ICP (2017) using the evolution of the price index relative to the reference country.
